query: Chino Grinder gravel race Chino Valley

videos.title: Chino Grinder 2025 Race Recap
videos.description:
Join me for onboard footage of the winning ride in the 2025 Chino Grinder gravel race. Chino Grinder is Arizona's longest-running gravel race, and at 107 miles and 8,400' of climbing, Chino is an attritional 5 hr+ race that is as much a test of one's will to keep pushing as it is a test of one's legs.

Thank-you to Spid Werkz Foundation for making this footage possible. Spid Werkz's mission is to support athletes from under-represented sports with gear, nutrition, and in-kind donations. If you like what you see here, please consider donating to Spid Werkz: https://spidwerkz.com/support/

Gear: For this race I'm on my Ventum GS1 gravel bike with 50mm Pirelli Cinturato M gravel tires. I had to do a little "tire surgery" and file off the side knobs of the rear tire to clear my frame, but the results speak for themselves. I used a 2L USWE hydration pack and two 20 oz bottles with Skratch ultra-high carb mix and NeverSecond energy gels,  targeting ~100g of carbohydrates per hour.
videos.transcript:
Welcome everyone to the 2025 Chino
Grinder race recap video. This is my
very first time doing a YouTube video
with commentary, so please bear with me.
Uh, it could be pretty painful. We'll
find out. Um, definitely want to get
your feedback on what you think of this
format, whether you like this, whether
you have any
suggestions for improvements.
Um, all kinds of feedback. Welcome.
Please leave some feedback in the
comments. I want to take a moment before
we get started here to recognize my one
of my sponsors, Spids Foundation, who
have so graciously provided me with
support this season, 2025. In fact, they
provided the GoPro that I used to record
this this uh race footage. So, let me
just say that a little bit of support
really goes a long way for athletes like
me. Spids is focused on supporting
athletes from traditionally
underrepresented sports like cycling and
rowing and their support has really been
instrumental for me this year in
achieving all of my goals and staying on
top and I raise nutrition. So please, if
you like what you see, consider donating
to Spids. I'm going to drop a link in
the video description. And with that,
let's get underway. So, here we're uh
just in the neutral roll out. A little
bit about the race. Uh Chino Grinder is
Arizona's longest running gravel race.
Uh I'm not sure exactly when they got
started, but it was at least before
2017. And uh here in the 2025 edition,
the course has been shortened ever so
slightly from around 120 mi to about
108.
Um, we have the addition of a different
uh out and back on the uh fire roads up
near Flagstaff, but the course is
substantially the same. It's a it's just
one great big long out and back as you
can see from the map in the upper left
corner. And uh one of the really
defining features of this race is uh the
long HC road climb that uh comes right
right in the middle of the race. So, uh,
as it turns out, it didn't actually end
up being very decisive, but, uh, we'll
get to that when we get to that. So, it,
uh, really quite cold at the start. You
can see here, we're uh, we've just hit
dirt for the first time. Uh, the sun is
coming up over the mountains. We're at
the coldest part of the day. Uh, start
temperatures were a little below 40° at
the start, so pretty nippy. But I'll
tell you, things really warmed up pretty
quick once we got moving and once the
sun rose. And I, you know, at this point
in the race, I was honestly really just
enjoying these views over the mountains.
I mean, look at that sunrise. Could you
ask for anything more? Um, the initial
portion of this race was uh, you know,
pretty low gradient climbing. Really,
just a lot of like 1 to 2%. Um, and the
roads have recently been regraded. So,
you can see here I've uh I've actually
pushed up and over the high point. Uh I
really made a point out of making sure
that I was going to attack and be the
first one up over the the first high
point so I could take the descent at my
speed uh with a clean line and with
clean vision. I mean, one thing that
doesn't uh often get talked about in
gravel races here is just how poor the
visibility can be. Um, particularly if
it's dry and dusty like it was on this
day, you get a lot of dust thrown up in
the air and then with the sunrise, it
can be very difficult to see. So, here I
really wanted to make sure that I was
the first one into the downhill and I
could really just focus on being, you
know, tucked in and aerodynamic and
taking whatever lines I wanted to
through the corners. So, this portion is
relatively straight, non-technical. Um,
I know that people are in my draft. I
know that they're getting a little bit
of a benefit from it, but the truth of
the matter is it's uh I I feel a lot
better to just be safe and to be in the
front in situations like that,
especially when there's still a lot of
people around. Um and this descent, you
know, it's not just a straight descent.
There's a few kickers like this. And I I
really like to make a point out of
pushing hard up and over each one of
these and really trying to maintain that
speed so that once I get up and over the
top, boom, just right back into an arrow
position and picking up as much steam as
possible. Um really I I had a coach and
a mentor who used to drill into me that
speed is king and it's all about
maintaining a constant high speed. You
can see here uh Justin Rea. This is a
pro triathlete and um he ended up second
on the day. Not to spoil things for
people, but uh you'll see him again a
lot as we as we move through this race.
Justin was super duper strong all day
long. And uh you know, he I was really
worried that uh I I wasn't going to be
able to deal with him. You can see he's
got me on a good gap here. And I'm I'm
not freaking out too much, but I'm I'm
pushing a little bit. I want to make
sure that I keep him close. There's
there's just no reason to let a gap open
here. It's just a straight non-technical
descent. So, I'm going to reel them in
nice and easy, just in the saddle,
focused on smooth pedal strokes and
power. And before we know it, we're
right back on the wheel.
Now, at this point, we're headed towards
some more technical switchbacks on the
descent. So, I really want to make sure
that I stay up at the front for this so
that I can really take those on my own
terms. So, here we go. We're getting
into the uh the more technical portion
of the first descent. And uh again, I've
I've really made sure that I stayed like
second or third wheel and that um I've
got my map screen up so I can see when
the turns are approaching. And I mean, I
think that that's really important,
being able to use the different screens
and the data that's available to you to
plan and make tactical maneuvers. So
here I've I pushed to be at the front
and we're making our way through the
first of uh two switchbacks. This one is
uh actually relatively mellow. It's more
of a double switch back. As you can see,
this is the the second aid station on
course and um the second to last one on
the way back. But as we come around the
corner here, um there's going to be like
a straight fast descent and then a
tighter, more technical switch back at
the bottom. So here I'm just I'm keeping
on the steam. I don't want anyone to
roll over the top of me here. I really
want to keep front wheel the whole way
through here until we get to the bottom
and then we'll regroup. So you know at
this point it's less about the power and
more just about positioning and staying
focused on um being smooth, being
relaxed and being aerodynamic.
So here we go rolling towards the second
switch back. Uh you can see the road has
recently been regraded and it's actually
in pretty good condition. So apart from
some washboards, it's not bad. But here
I really try to take this corner at at
maximum speed. I aim for the inside of
the apex of the corner and try to
maintain straight line as possible and
then really up onto the pedals out of
the saddle. Focused on getting back up
to speed as quickly as I can through
there.
Now
um at this point, you know, we're we're
we're nearly to the bottom. I know
there's going to be a regrouping. I know
that a lot of people are behind me, but
they're they're not getting much of a
benefit from me drafting me at this
point, right? There's there's uh a lot
of gaps opening up behind us. So, here
we go. Fast forward to the top of the
road climb. I'll spare you all the
tedious details. Like, frankly, it was
pretty neutral most of the way up, but
Justin, he was just so so so strong on
this whole climb. And honestly, if he
hadn't uh dropped his base layer into
his chain and gotten it tangled up and
had to spend a I don't know, a minute,
two minutes fishing it out, oh, he could
have done some real real damage to us
all here. As it was, he he pulled back
that gap all on his own. Went straight
to the front. And you can see here, he's
out of the saddle, putting us all under
pressure. And I'm going to be honest,
this was one of the one of the moments
uh during the race where I felt like I
was under the most pressure. I know
we're near the high point, so I can just
really focus on holding that wheel. Dig
deep, get out of the saddle, do whatever
it takes. Don't let him get away from
me, cuz I know I'm going to get some
recovery soon. And really, in moments
like that, you know, you got to just
kind of keep the faith and just think,
oh, if I can make it another 10 seconds,
if I can make it another 15 seconds,
then things are going to get better. I'm
going to be able to recover. And sure
enough, you know, as we begin to roll
over the top, it's going to flatten out
and I'm going to start getting a much
greater draft benefit from being able to
sit on Justin's wheel. But he was uh he
he really had a lot of gas left in the
tank at this point. So, very impressive
stuff.
Now, uh, at this point, you know, we're
going to we're going to begin descending
on the new outback portion that, uh,
that goes down into, uh, the turnaround
point at 54 miles. And, uh, this is
around the time I started realizing that
I was having some mechanical problems.
So, you can see here, Justin is, you
know, maybe not quite as confident as I
am, uh, going through these corners.
I've really put in a lot of work this
year um to improve my gravel descending.
It's I've I've put in a lot of work on
descents like Mount Hopkins and I've
been doing a lot of mountain bike racing
too and I really feel like it's paying
off. You can see especially through this
corner, Justin kind of runs a little bit
wide while I make sure I stay very far
inside so I can ride the banked surface
of the road where it drains off to the
right and I can carry so much more speed
through there and with a lot more
confidence.
Now, all that's great, but
confidence is about to run out once I
realize that um I'm having some brake
problems. Uh so, uh you know, I'm on
hydraulic brakes, as pretty much
everyone is here in the 21st century. I
store my bikes on a rack standing
vertically, and in order to get them all
fit, I got to store some of them
basically upside down with the handle
bars pointed towards the ground. The
gravel bike is one of them. As it turns
out, that can sometimes have some
effects on uh where bubbles, if there
are any, in your hydraulic brake system
go. And uh as we'll see here at this
hair pin at the bottom, um I had
basically lost all of my front brake.
And I start to realize and so I'm
pulling the rear and I'm skipping a
little bit. I'm just trying not to lose
composure, not to uncip. I run wide off
the side of the road, but you know, just
kind of staying focused and and trying
to stay cool and calm, managed to keep
it up and not take anyone to the ground
with me. So, thank goodness that wasn't
the only time that happened in this
race.
Now, at this point, we've made it back
to the road. Uh we've climbed up and out
of Matan and Maxwell Ry. So, Matan Suler
is one of my one of my teammates. He was
in the neon green Landis Trek jersey.
Um, and Maxwell Ry, another very
talented Catwoman cyclist who's just
moved to Arizona. Uh, they've been
dropped. So, it's just me and Justin Rea
at this point. And I'm pretty thankful
to have a a companion for this descent,
especially kind of a a stockier, more
powerful rider like uh like Justin who
can really uh plow through the wind and
and give me a nice draft down a long
descent like this. But I'll say that
even even now on this descent where
we're doing 40 m hour and we're not
pedaling. I was beginning to have some
inklings that, you know, Justin might be
starting to feel the efforts a bit. He
he uh was again, I cannot emphasize
enough, just so strong all day long. Um,
but he ended up stopping a couple of
times. uh once for the for the clothing
snafu and a second time to take a
hydration pack at the aid station where
I decided I'm going to take two big
bottles. I'm going to take 2 lers of
water in my hydration pack. I'm going to
take that weight penalty and I'm going
to make sure I don't have to stop a
single time in this entire race. And I
can see even on this descent, he's
starting to, you know, not really pull
very hard as we're as we're going down.
So, um, now we're we're making our way
back onto the dirt and, uh,
this is where, uh, some of the real
tells start to show. So, as we as we
begin making our way, um, onto the dirt,
we we kind of pass through a sector with
some some rolling punchy climbs uh,
before we do a slightly technical
descent back to the low point of the
course. And um as we'll see here shortly
uh on some of these short kickers, you
know, I'm really I'm really
focused on keeping the speed high. So
here we go. We're doing like 32 mph
here. Still going downhill a little bit,
but boom. About to hit one of the
steepest kickers on course. It's not
very much to look at here, but you know,
you got to keep in mind we're about
three and a half hours into the race.
It's been hard. So, here we go. Up out
of the saddle. You can see instantly I'm
already up in front of Justin's wheel.
You know, he's uh he's he's still
staying with it. He's make no mistake,
he latches right onto my wheel after
this. But this is just kind of goes to
show that like yeah, if Justin was
feeling great, if he was feeling like he
could, you know, work me over later on
in this race, there's probably no way he
lets me get in front of him at this
point. So, up and over the top. Make
sure we get back up to speed.
Unfortunately, I didn't have the GoPro
running during the uh descent down to
Perkinsville. But here we go. This is
the final climb out from Perkinsville up
to the last high point before the final
10 miles, which are basically all
downhill. At this point, I've managed to
drop Justin. I'm driving the dagger in.
I've basically just surged one time too
many for him. We're at hour about four
hours 15 minutes. It's been really,
really hard all day long. And here I'm
really surprised at how good I was still
feeling. I knew that at this point, you
know, I've got the separation. I need to
keep staying on the gas. I got to really
drive this whole thing home. And you
know, I I remember early on when I was
learning how to race road bikes, someone
told me, you know, once you got a gap,
you really got to just basically step on
their neck. You know, don't let them up
for air. Bury them 6 ft deep. And
especially knowing that the last 10
miles is kind of a false flat downhill
that's much better suited to uh like a
steady power guy like Justin, you know,
kind of stockier, bigger guy who's going
to roll really fast down that. I know I
need to pat out my advantage as much as
I possibly can here on the uphill. So,
I'm all in 100% full gas. And let me
tell you, I was pretty empty by the time
we hit the high point. But from there,
it was just all about staying focused,
staying arrow, and making my way to the
finish and finally being able to lift my
arms in celebration of being the first
finisher of the 108 mile long course at
Chino Grinder. So really, I just want to
say once again, thank you Spids for your
support throughout this entire season,
and thank you to each and every one of
you who decided to tune in and watch
this whole video recap. Really enjoyed
it. Hoping I can bring some more footage
to you again soon from Spirit World in
Patagonia.

videos.title: 2023 Chino Valley Grinder-Half Grinder Start (60 mile).
videos.description: Big field for the 2023 Chino Valley Grinder, half grind (60 milers). The full grind (120 miles) started 30 minutes earlier with a smaller field (understandably). Chino Valley, Arizona. #gravelbike #gravelride  @shendocatracing

videos.title: Chino grinder Presented by Shendo Cat Racing
videos.description: Just a little sump'n about the Chino Grinder gravel grinder in Chino Valley, AZ.

videos.title: Gravel Grinder 2023 in Chino Valley
videos.description: 4k video on my Insta360 Camera.  This isthe first 30 min of the 60 miler.  Big group with a fast start.  My first gravel race was Hella fun.#gravelbike #gravelracing #chinovalley #360video

videos.title: 2025 Chino Valley Gravel Bike Race Vlog...and Knitting
videos.channel: Knitter by Day, Cage Fighter by Night
videos.description: Watch me car camping, complete a 22 ish mile gravel bike race and check out a local yarn store. #cycling #mma #thaiboxinglife #gravelbike #knitting #yarnstore #carcamping #arizona
